title: French Style Fonts
content:
Hey guys, I'm designing a flyer for a screening of the french film 'Mouchette' and I'm having trouble finding the right font. I am looking for something that is sort of classically french, but I am open to anything you guys might think appropriate. I just know that I don't have anything that I think will work.

Thanks.
author: bigcitykent

I agree with Carl that one shouldn't be too literal. On the other hand, I'm sure he agrees with me that typefaces do have associations, and it <cite>is</cite> a French movie (and the character isn't French by "accident") so it's a bonus if the font has something French about it. All this means that the French angle should be just another factor, and not anything central. But since there are so many fonts out there, it is a nice way to narrow things down.

Considering the movie seems to be a dark but human tale, I think Peignot is too playful (although the youth angle might make it click) and Didot/Bodoni is too cold. Just mentioning two things from the top of my head: Beorcana (one of its superb dark weights) or ITC Mendoza.

Mouchette was released in 1967 at the peak of the French New Wave. For that period, your best text face is Vendome, used for heads in all the hot paperbacks the French read at the time. If you want an earlier French look, FF Acanthus or Andrade from MyFonts are very authentic. If you want late 19th century, ITC Bodoni Twelve serves very well. Peignot, however, is too specific, Parisian, and touristy, so avoid that choice. And Antique Olive is appropriate to nothing here--ugh! The original poster shows a crude block display face, which can be found at any of the free font sites, but you still need a proper text face, and for that, think of what would go with the world of cinema-going at that time--Vendome.

Hi  
I think you should try Vendome (see [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/urw/vendome/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150313163246/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/urw/vendome/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/urw/vendome/")) : it's typically French, released roughly at the same time, and with a lot of literary connotations which are quite appropriate for Bresson's movies — "Mouchette" is from a novel by Bernanos, after all.

BTW, if you (ever) need a texty companion to Vendome, try Meridien.
